newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft unveils new Web-based online network.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft unveils new Web-based online network.

text.p: Microsoft Corp., pursuing its vow of becoming a dominant force in the Internet market, unveiled a new World Wide Web-based version of its Microsoft Network Thursday and announced new pricing for the service.

Microsoft said the new version of its online service, already the third-largest online service in the world, will offer new services, original entertainment programming and a "program viewer" that puts members just a click away from any major area on the entire Internet.
"People tell us two things about going on the Internet -- that there is nothing there, and that there's so much there they can't find anything," said Pete Higgins, a Microsoft group vice president.

"Our goal with the new Microsoft Network is to address both issues, combining a lot of essential services, original entertainment and new information in one place and making the rest of the Internet easier to approach and enjoy."

Microsoft, the world's largest software company, said a "sneak preview" of its new network, also known as MSN, was now underway for more than 100,000 of its 1.6 million customers, with full roll-out scheduled for early November.

The company said the basic monthly plan will offer five hours of access to the Internet, electronic-mail and all MSN services and original programming for $6.95 per month, with additional hours at $2.50.
A premier plan offers unlimited access for $19.95 per month. A third plan, aimed at users who already have Internet access, will offer unlimited usage of all MSN content for only $6.95 per month.

For those who already have access to the Internet, a number of MSN services, such as Expedia travel services, Microsoft Investor investing service and MSNBC, the company's all-news collaboration with NBC, will be free.

"Our goal with the new Microsoft Network is to bridge the gap between what users expect from the Internet and what has so far been delivered," said Laura Jennings, vice president of the Microsoft Network.
"The new MSN brings the Internet to life with an engaging multimedia interface that guides members with ease through original programming, useful services and the entire Internet."

The company said its new programme viewer, based on its Internet Explorer browser, is organised into four main areas -- OnStage, Communicate, Find and Essentials -- that correspond to what most people want to do online.
OnStage is the news and entertainment area MSN, featuring six channels and more than 20 Web "shows."
The Communicate area of the programme viewer will provide an easy way to use e-mail, participate in chats, enter discussion forums and access Internet newsgroups, the company said.
The Find area will simplify the searching process, helping users to locate topics of interest without the frustration of random searches.
In addition, members can select from the Internet's most popular search engines -- AltaVista, Yahoo! and Lycos, plus Deja News, an Internet newsgroup search engine -- for more targeted searches.
The Essentials area of the programme viewer will make key services available online so members can find time-saving information and make purchases.
"Our goal was to create a network that is easy to use, is well-produced and makes sense of a new medium for our audience," said Bob Bejan, executive producer of Microsoft Network.
"MSN takes our members from being spectators of mass media to being collaborators in mass media, and does so in a way that is engaging, informative and entertaining."
Microsoft's stock added 87.50 cents to $135.375 in early afternoon trading on the Nasdaq market.
